awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Aided Part Identification for Coordinate Measuring Machines
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a new generation of smart machines used in the measurement of parts and assemblies. The team has demonstrated that this technology can convert existing coordinate measuring machines to self-driving autonomous machines. The ability to automatically measure parts is an important feedback link in the process chain that will enable fully automated manufacturing of the future. Specifically, this automation will reduce the specialized skill required to use a Coordinate Measuring Machine (CMM). The innovation will enable workers to operate a CMM and get a precise part measurement. This device is especially helpful as the skilled manufacturing/metrology workforce is retiring as it gives new employees the ability to provide accurate information with little/no training. This innovation also gives the manufacturing companies an option to buy a new machine or upgrade their existing coordinate measuring machine. While the focus of this proposal is part identification, this technology has ready applications in Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machining, robotics, and automated assembly lines. This capability will make the US manufacturing sector stronger and more technologically advanced.

The objective of this proposal is to develop a new technology to identify machined parts and assemblies. This technology will be implemented on coordinate measuring machines (CMM), which are used widely in the manufacturing sector to measure the shape and size of parts. The proposed technology will enable autonomous measurements of parts allowing a higher level of automation. In this identification technology, the team will use live images from a camera, multiple solid model/Computer Aided Design (CAD)-generated images, and advanced image processing. Applying Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML) to the image processing of part images will ensure correct part identification. Correct identification of parts as seen by the camera is the remaining unsolved challenge to achieving self-driven automatic measurements of parts. Most machined parts are textureless and most of the information is contained in the edges. Current image processing techniques work well with texture-rich parts but are unreliable with textureless machined parts. AI/ML enhanced image processing using edge and shape information is a promising approach, solving this problem will lead to the birth of a new generation of CMMs that can measure parts automatically.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The NSF SBIR Phase I project, "Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Aided Object Identification for Coordinate Measuring Machines," has developed innovative technology for the manufacturing sector to accurately and swiftly identify objects for measurement. Our primary goal is to integrate this technology into Coordinate Measuring Machines (CMMs), which are extensively used to measure the geometry of objects. Currently, skilled CMM operators are required for this task, but there is a growing shortage of such skilled workers. Integrating this Phase I object identification technology into CMMs will enable autonomous measurements without operator intervention, thereby increasing automation in manufacturing.

The object identification process in this project follows a sequence of steps. First, a camera captures an image of the scene. Next, a region containing an object of interest is extracted, and the object is identified from a known library of objects. The goal is to achieve accurate identification in the shortest possible time.

Our technology leverages live images from a camera, solid models, and advanced image processing techniques. By combining image processing with AI and Machine Learning (ML), we achieved high accuracy in object identification. Ensuring the correct identification of objects captured by the camera was the last major hurdle in realizing autonomous object measurements. Overcoming this challenge has enabled the development of a new generation of CMMs capable of automatic object measurement.

This advancement significantly reduces reliance on skilled labor, a critical factor given the current shortage of skilled workers in the manufacturing sector. Minimizing the need for human intervention in the measurement process increases productivity and ensures greater consistency and accuracy in measurements, reducing the potential for human error and leading to higher quality control and more reliable manufacturing outcomes.

We tested our technology's robustness in handling variations in object appearance due to different angles and lighting conditions. By training the models with diverse datasets, we ensured the system could accurately identify objects in various real-world scenarios. This adaptability is crucial for deployment in diverse manufacturing settings where conditions frequently change. Traditional image processing techniques often struggled with variability in object appearance caused by differences in viewing angles, lighting conditions, and other environmental factors. By leveraging AI and ML, our system learned to recognize objects despite these variations, ensuring a higher rate of accurate identification.

One of the critical benefits of this technology is its impact on reducing human error. In traditional CMM operations, skilled operators manually identify and measure objects, a time-consuming and error-prone process, especially when dealing with complex objects or large volumes of measurements. Our autonomous system eliminates these issues by providing consistent and accurate measurements every time. The reduction in reliance on skilled labor addresses a significant industry challenge. The manufacturing sector faces a growing shortage of skilled workers, exacerbated by the retirement of the baby-boomer generation and a lack of younger workers entering the field. By automating the object identification and measurement process, our technology enables less skilled workers to perform these tasks, thereby filling the gap left by the skilled labor shortage.

The implementation of our technology has broader implications for the manufacturing industry. The ability to automatically and accurately measure objects is a critical component of the "smart factories" of the future, which leverage advanced technologies to create highly efficient and flexible manufacturing processes. The object identification technology developed in this Phase I project enables autonomous CMMs on the manufacturing floor, providing the autonomous measurements needed to maintain high quality and efficiency.

Our technology's robustness and versatility make it suitable for a wide range of applications. While our initial focus was on bridge-type CMMs, the principles and techniques we developed are applicable to other areas of manufacturing. For example, the ability to accurately identify and measure objects is crucial in CNC machining, industrial robots, surgical robots, automated assembly lines, and logistics.

The broader impacts of our technology extend beyond immediate benefits to the manufacturing sector. The development of this technology opens new avenues for research and innovation. The intersection of vision, metrology, robotics, motion control, and machine learning/AI is a rich area for exploration, and our work in object identification will support future advancements in these fields.

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2024
Modified by: Bing Zhao
